column4: Hey. I have ubuntu Intrepid and I'm trying to run a cron job (just testing by trying to open xterm) and it isn't working. After checking the mail from cron I get: Invalid MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1 keyxterm Xt error: Can't open display: :0. What do I do?
You normally do not run gui apps as cron jobs - since cron may not be running them as the same user thats using the X dislay at that time
well it worked in hardy just fine
xterm -display :0
sounds like they plugged a security hole.
if you really need to do it I guess ya could  find some work around..
I believe it is something to do with Xauthority.
yep. that would be my guess also.. the xhost command may let ya get around that.. with the new  user-switching  features of 8.10   i imagine they locked that stuff down as much as they can
what about xhost?
it can disable some of that security features
hmm how do I use it?

i would start with 'man xhost'  im proper use of it can be considerd a big security hole.. 'xhost +localhost'  used to allow anyonton the local machine to access the X display.. Not sure if it still does..
the person RUNNING the X server/logged in. uses the command to allow otehrs to run apps on his display
some good info here.. (hard core info) --> http://www.oceanwave.com/technical-resources/unix-admin/security/x-security.html
sorry about that. Ok so cron works. mplayer worked fine. And I'm almost certain it has something to do with xauth. What do I do to allow it to run xterm?
i would say read up on that x security site i posted earlier.. it details how to allow other users to access the desktop with the xauth system.  I wonder how mplayer 'works' but not xterm...
I am the sole user on the computer...
so.. :) cron is not running as that user..
if you need apps to run at specific times I belive there are some alarm type apps that can do that.. you dont need to use cron
True but it's easy with cron. Well it was in hardy. What changed since then?
no idea.   the forums may tell you
figured it out. Had to run xhost +. Apparently Intrepid is stricter with x stuff and for some reason wouldn't allow xterm to run even though it's from localhost
